lines.text: My orders are to take this base.
My orders are to stop you.
You have no chance. I appeal to you to surrender.
Let me tell you something, Russian. That spot that you're standing on happens to be a part of the United States and my job is to defend it.
I understand you. I am a soldier too.
Is that all you have to say? "Surrender"?
I no longer have the stomach to kill you.

Why not? You've had plenty of stomach for it so far. You've killed innocent civilians, anybody who happened to be around. You've killed boys who hardly know how to handle a gun. You've killed people that I care about who were doing their best to prevent an invasion of their country.
You know as well as I do that we don't kill people. We simply inflict casualties on the other side. This little war is no longer the full story, Colonel. Our leaders have much bigger ideas.
I know that. The end?
And what have you to say about that?
I have always believed that the finest ambition of the soldier is to prevent war from ever happening but it has always been out of our hands. It's in the hands of men whom we don't even know.
Shall we deprive them of our services?
Well at least we can tell them we've done our job and now it's time for them to do theirs.
We are in agreement.
Should that be happening? Two soldiers talking to each other, that it would be the end of war?
Perhaps the time has come for that. Let us end this particular war right here. I will say to them I have met my enemy and he is no longer my enemy.
Oh yes, a birthday message to Secretary General Gorny. You know what I'd like to send that Soviet so-and-so?
25 megatons of candles right up his...
No, Wayne. 25 megatons of wheat.
Wheat, sir?
He's behaved himself. No candles. I may get creamed in November but I'll be damned if I leave the next President a pile of ashes in lieu of a country.
I'm afraid I've reached that age when sex is constantly on my mind but rarely on my agenda.
The sad thing about death, Major, is they don't even know they've died.
I would like to think there is still some meaning to all this.
A soldier doesn't ask for meaning, Comrade. He asks for information and further instructions. That is what we will get.
We are looking at the possibility of a nuclear confrontation.
But no one's going win a nuclear confrontation.
That has nothing to do with getting into one.

[Outside an oil pumping station in Alaska]
Do you think it will be worth it for them to die for a piece of machinery?
Ideology, Major. That's your subject, isn't it? They will fight for the ideal of that place and all the ideas connected with it.
And where do people get those ideas? From men like me.
In Stalingrad my father fought for a steel plant that looked like a pile of rubble. It wasn't the steel plant, it was what it represented to the Russian people.
[Looks towards the pumping station]
Well, then that's their Stalingrad.
